This is very poorly argued.  Like so many of Douthat's pronouncements, here, yet again, he is evasive -- and circular in his reasoning.  Why?  Because he seeks to obscure his personal beliefs in a cloak of reason.  He fails.  His so-called argument?  He says that interest in traditional marriage among straights is declining.  True.  He says that acceptance of same-sex marriage has increased.  True.  He says that the two are related in "a kind of feekback loop."  Maybe.  Here, Douthat is being disingenuous.  He sees homosexuality as decadent, yet in order to preserve his intellectual veneer, he tries to prove some vague decline in the entire culture.  There is no rational argument that I have yet heard that equal rights for all inherently undermine values that would support strong families.  But Douthat has a narrow model in mind for such families, and wishes, in vain, that a single model should prevail.  So, why not just say so?   Here is the despicable truth behind his evasion and faux rationalizing: because he is writing on this day of all days, he does so to declare, in polite terms, his animus to homosexuality.

Doug......Interesting that after you stopped being immersed as a reporter in the daily DC political battles, that you could "see the stripped down truth from a safer distance," and be appalled. Which is the only sane response.  So much of our media people are 'in it', and absorb the values of our distorted political culture. Whether 'liberals' or not.

Every day as a reporter, I tried to find and report the truth. It wasn't that difficult to catch officials and members of Congress in distortions, mistakes and occasional outright lies, but it was difficult to get anyone to believe that, once exposed, they should care.

Yes, I do accept, to a degree, that it is easier now to see clearly away from the fray. I also think our politics have gotten much worse, much more blatant and for that I blame not only the massive sums of money flowing but also political consultants who make their money by seeing sharp angles and getting politicians to play them, full time.

One other thing. As a reporter, I trained myself not to take sides. I didn't formulate opinions about everything going on (unlike the "reporters" on talk shows who sound like they know everything). I specifically refrained from developing opinions and instead tried to look at the impact of actions on people across the nation.

In trying to be professional and withholding bias, a major part of the story of govt. and politics gets left out. If you can't report the background of why politicians are doing what they are doing, it is like walking blind without a cane. Sportscasters often do a much better job than political reporters.

Republicans have been saying that Obama "forced" the ACA on the American public since it first passed. How did he force it? They held a vote in Congress. Oh, the shame.

One Republican and far right claim is the President "rammed it down our throats". How? By holding a vote in Congress.

The Republicans made a solemn pact that no Republican would cooperate in making changes to the ACA and all agreed to vote against it. Since this made it appear that it was a purely partisan piece of legislation, then they could claim that Obama forced it on the public. They created conditions of non-cooperation and then blamed Obama because they wouldn't cooperate.

This kind of political tricksterism doesn't bother me. Much. I might in an idle moment imagine or hope that we, as fellow citizens in a cooperative nation, wouldn't play such silly games, but I know that is not realistic in our rancid political climate. What does bother me is, 1. So many people don't know the actual facts of how these things are shaped to gain political advantage and, 2. So many people accept the distorted arguments as ultimate truth and then repeat their these orchestrated conclusions in every available forum.

I used to wallow in daily political battles as a reporter on Capitol Hill, at the White House and elsewhere, but now that I see the stripped down truth from a safer distance, I am appalled. We all should be. We don't make progress by shouting lies at each other, dudes.

This includes you, Jeb Bush.

@ Dan88 — It is unlikely in the extreme that any prosecutor would ever bother to seek to file criminal charges in such an incident. The cost of prosecuting such a trivial offense, in terms of both time and money, would be an irrational allocation of resources. That’s especially so when it occurs in the course of an athletic event held under the auspices of a private organization, such as the United States Soccer Federation, and where the player is part of a league, MLS in this case, both of which will impose disciplinary sanctions for on-field misconduct.

By way of comparison, think of the bench-clearing brawls that happen in baseball a few times a season. In some of those, players actually hit each other. Those incidents certainly •could• be prosecuted as battery, but I can’t remember when that last happened, if ever.

It might happen, if a really serious injury resulted, or if anyone grabbed a bat and started swinging it as a weapon (something that simply •doesn’t• happen, because all baseball players would see it as beyond the pale, in the unwritten “rules” of those incidents). And if someone were •killed•, a criminal investigation most certainly would ensue.

But ordinarily, it’s simply not worth it for prosecutors to get involved.

— Brian
